The Welch Food, Inc., is proud to inform all interested parties that our company is complying with OSHA's Process Safety Management Standard (PSM), Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations 1910.119, and EPA's Risk Management Program regulations (RMP), Title 40 CFR Part 68. In addition to other state and local codes applicable to our facility and process. We have undertaken this process to deal with the risks involved with the storage, handling, and use of Anhydrous Ammonia in our facility.



Our goal is to promote overall worker, public, and plant safety. The Welch Food, Inc. facility is located at 100 N. Portage Street, Westfield, NY. Welch's Westfield Plant is a grape processing and storage facility.  The facility includes but is not limited to processing tanks, piping, , raw materials warehousing, finished goods refrigerated storage, miscellaneous utilities, and two ammonia refrigeration systems that share the same engine room. Also, located at the facility is shipping and receiving docks. 



The facility has 2 separate ammonia systems and produces and shipped approximately.  The refrigeration systems exceed the 10,000 pound threshold required for our production process and necessitates the submission of this Risk Management Plan. 



A Worst ad Alternate Case Scenario were calculated for this Risk Management Plan. A Worst Case Scenario was used with a liquid release totaling roughly 6500 pounds over ten minutes with a release radius of 0.91 mile.  An Alternate Case Scenario was used with a liquid release totaling roughly 700 pounds over ten minutes with a release radius of 0.30 mile.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

The Welch Food, Inc. is in the process of implementing numerous policies and procedures to enable our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences of significant releases of Anhydrous Ammonia as well as other hazardous substances, fires, explosions, and other types of catastrophic accidents. Overall

these programs prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, and illnesses and avoid property damage.  Our safety programs prevent accidents because they focus on the rules, procedures, and practices, which govern individual processes, activities, or pieces of equipment. These rules are communicated to and accepted by all employees at our facility.

The Welch Food, Inc. Process Safety Management / Risk Management Program is in the process of being developed and implemented. This program will be organize the information and polices pertaining to the process into a complete library. 



Volume 1 of the PSM/RMP Library incorporates several policies. Many policies are included in Volume 1, the remaining are referenced from other training manuals maintained in the facility.



Employee Participation Guidelines: This policy outlines the commitment between management and employees to establish a program for a successful (safe) program.



Process Safety Information: This includes information on the ammonia inventory at the facility, applicable codes, design standards, and information pertaining to the hazards of ammonia (referenced from the IIAR ammonia Data Book).



Process Hazard Analysis Program: This program outlines a thorough, orderly, systematic approach for identifying, evaluating, and controlling potential hazards within a process involving potentially hazardous chemicals such as ammonia.



Operating Procedures: develop, implement, and maintain clearly written, detailed procedures, guidelines, rules, and practices for the safe operation of the ammonia refrigeration process during all operating phases. The operating procedures provide all employees involved in the operation and maintenance of the ammonia refrigeration process with the written information and precautions necessary to safety perform their tasks in a consistent manner.



Contractor Qualification Guidelines: This guideline has been established to verify that the contractors working in the facility are q

ualified to work on the system, trained in the hazards associated with their work, and made aware of the hazards presented by the facility to the employees of the contractor.



Management of Change and Pre-Startup Safety Review Programs: These programs have been developed to monitor and provide a "checks and balances" system to monitor changes in the facility and to verify that changes are safe and consistent with company policy.



Mechanical Integrity Program: To prevent or minimize the consequences of catastrophic releases of ammonia, it is important to ensure process equipment is maintained properly. The purpose of an MI program is to maintain process equipment so that a catastrophic release of ammonia is avoided or properly contained. The emphasis should be on preventive maintenance rather than breakdown maintenance.



Many more specific programs and policies (Hot Work, Confined Space, Lockout / Tagout, Employee training, etc.) have been developed. For information specific to these see the Operations Manager.



Process Hazard Analysis Re-validation was completed in 2012..  The PHA highlighted some deficiencies in the system. These items were addressed as part of the continuous improvement of the facility. These items were addressed on the basis of priority (Injuries to personnel). 



Procedures for conducting Compliance Audits, Mechanical Integrity Inspections, and Process Hazard Analyses are also in development.



Many more specific programs and policies (Hot Work, Confined Space, Lockout / Tagout, etc.) have been developed. For information specific to these see the Safety Director.



Volume 2 incorporates information on the specific system components (Pumps, vessels, compressors, evaporators, evaporative condensers, purgers, piping systems, heat exchangers, the emergency ventilation system, and general safety). This information is used as a reference source for the operator to positively identify system components. This manual also provides a checklist

for performing the yearly Mechanical Integrity Inspection.

Volume 3 incorporates a complete valve list. The valve list contains information on the type, port size, identifying number, use, location, model, manufacturer, drawing reference, and normal operating position of each valve in the system.



Also included in Volume 3 is the Process and Instrumentation Diagrams for the individual system components. Flow schematics are included showing the entire system. A Block flow diagram provides a brief overview of the system. Drawings are included showing symbol and abbreviation descriptions. Plan views are included to allow the operator to physically locate equipment in the building.



Volume 4 will incorporate a complete set of standard operating procedures, describing the proper steps for preparing components for start-up, starting components, monitoring normal operation of system components, shutting down components as part of normal operation, restarting equipment as part of normal operation, shutting down equipment for maintenance, restarting equipment after maintenance, shutting down equipment in emergency situations, restarting equipment after an emergency situations shutdown, and pumpout procedures. Also included as a part of each Standard Operating Procedure is the Technical Operating Specifications for the associated system component. This information includes consequences of deviation from standard operating procedures.



Volume 5 contains Operation and Maintenance Information including manufactures information, spare parts list, maintenance procedures, and preventive maintenance procedures.



PROCESS DESCRIPTION

The Welch Food, Inc. also incorporates the ammonia refrigeration system at The Welch Food, Inc. is a standard compression and evaporation style system. The Welch Food, Inc., is a food based processing and distribution facility. 

5 YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The Welch Food, Inc. has had no reportable releases at our facility in the last 5 years.

EMERGENCY ACTION PLAN

The Welch Food, Inc. has an Emergency Action Plan to establish procedures and guidelines to provide prompt and orderly action to emergencies involving the release of hazardous materials to prevent or minimize the potential health or environmental effects caused by such a release. The plan utilizes local emergency responders and contractors.



The Plan establishes lines of authority for conducting safe response operations, personnel roles and training, and communication procedures.  All employees are expected to comply with the plan in order to assure its effectiveness.



The plan provides guidelines for determining emergency recognition, proper levels of action, emergency communication, security and control.



A communication chain of command has been established to assure prompt and efficient action to any hazardous material spill or leak and effective coordination with the Fire Department. 



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Welch Foods, Inc. is committed to continuous improvement of our policies, procedures, and facility. It is the intention of Welch Foods, Inc. to remain an industry leader. New technology, training techniques, and equipment are continuously being added to our system.

Our Preventative Maintenance Program was recently revamped with the inclusion of IIAR-6, while IIAR-9 will be implemented over the next few months.
